Provably Secure Federated Learning against Malicious Clients

Xiaoyu Cao, Jinyuan Jia, Neil Zhenqiang Gong
Abstract

Federated learning enables clients to collaboratively learn a shared global model without sharing their local training data with a cloud server. However, malicious clients can corrupt the global model to predict incorrect labels for testing examples. Existing defenses against malicious clients leverage Byzantine-robust federated learning methods. However, these methods cannot provably guarantee that the predicted label for a testing example is not affected by malicious clients. We bridge this gap via ensemble federated learning. In particular, given any base federated learning algorithm, we use the algorithm to learn multiple global models, each of which is learnt using a randomly selected subset of clients. When predicting the label of a testing example, we take majority vote among the global models. We show that our ensemble federated learning with any base federated learning algorithm is provably secure against malicious clients. Specifically, the label predicted by our ensemble global model for a testing example is provably not affected by a bounded number of malicious clients. Moreover, we show that our derived bound is tight. We evaluate our method on MNIST and Human Activity Recognition datasets. For instance, our method can achieve a certified accuracy of 88% on MNIST when 20 out of 1,000 clients are malicious.

Introduction

Federated learning (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. 2016; McMahan etÂ al. 2017) is an emerging machine learning paradigm, which enables many clients (e.g., smartphones, IoT devices, and organizations) to collaboratively learn a model without sharing their local training data with a cloud server. Due to its promise for protecting privacy of the clientsâ€™ local training data and the emerging privacy regulations such as General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), federated learning has been deployed by industry. For instance, Google has deployed federated learning for next-word prediction on Android Gboard. Existing federated learning methods mainly follow a single-global-model paradigm. Specifically, a cloud server maintains a global model and each client maintains a local model. The global model is trained via multiple iterations of communications between the clients and server. In each iteration, three steps are performed: 1) the server sends the current global model to the clients; 2) the clients update their local models based on the global model and their local training data, and send the model updates to the server; and 3) the server aggregates the model updates and uses them to update the global model. The learnt global model is then used to predict labels of testing examples.

However, such single-global-model paradigm is vulnerable to security attacks. In particular, an attacker can inject fake clients to federated learning or compromise existing clients, where we call the fake/compromised clients malicious clients. Such malicious clients can corrupt the global model via carefully tampering their local training data or model updates sent to the server. As a result, the corrupted global model has a low accuracy for the normal testing examples (Fang etÂ al. 2020; Xie, Koyejo, and Gupta 2019) or certain attacker-chosen testing examplesÂ (Bagdasaryan etÂ al. 2020; Bhagoji etÂ al. 2019; Xie etÂ al. 2020). For instance, when learning an image classifier, the malicious clients can re-label the cars with certain strips as birds in their local training data and scale up their model updates sent to the server, such that the learnt global model incorrectly predicts a car with the strips as bird (Bagdasaryan etÂ al. 2020).

Various Byzantine-robust federated learning methods have been proposed to defend against malicious clients (Blanchard etÂ al. 2017; Chen, Su, and Xu 2017; Mhamdi, Guerraoui, and Rouault 2018; Yin etÂ al. 2018, 2019; Chen etÂ al. 2018; Alistarh, Allen-Zhu, and Li 2018). The main idea of these methods is to mitigate the impact of statistical outliers among the clientsâ€™ model updates. They can bound the difference between the global model parameters learnt without malicious clients and the global model parameters learnt when some clients become malicious. However, these methods cannot provably guarantee that the label predicted by the global model for a testing example is not affected by malicious clients. Indeed, studies showed that malicious clients can still substantially degrade the testing accuracy of a global model learnt by a Byzantine-robust method via carefully tampering their model updates sent to the serverÂ (Bhagoji etÂ al. 2019; Fang etÂ al. 2020; Xie, Koyejo, and Gupta 2019).

In this work, we propose ensemble federated learning, the first federated learning method that is provably secure against malicious clients. Specifically, given nğ‘›n clients, we define a subsample as a set of kğ‘˜k clients sampled from the nğ‘›n clients uniformly at random without replacement. For each subsample, we can learn a global model using a base federated learning algorithm with the kğ‘˜k clients in the subsample. Since there are (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} subsamples with kğ‘˜k clients, (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models can be trained in total. Suppose we are given a testing example ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. We define pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} as the fraction of the (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models that predict label iğ‘–i for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, where i=1,2,â‹¯,Lğ‘–12â‹¯ğ¿i=1,2,\cdots,L. We call pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} label probability. Our ensemble global model predicts the label with the largest label probability for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. In other words, our ensemble global model takes a majority vote among the global models to predict label for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. Since each global model is learnt using a subsample with kğ‘˜k clients, a majority of the global models are learnt using normal clients when most clients are normal. Therefore, the majority vote among the global models is secure against a bounded number of malicious clients.

Theory:Â  Our first major theoretical result is that our ensemble global model provably predicts the same label for a testing example ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} when the number of malicious clients is no larger than a threshold, which we call certified security level. Our second major theoretical result is that we prove our derived certified security level is tight, i.e., when no assumptions are made on the base federated learning algorithm, it is impossible to derive a certified security level that is larger than ours. Note that the certified security level may be different for different testing examples.

Algorithm:Â  Computing our certified security level for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} requires its largest and second largest label probabilities. When (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} is small (e.g., the nğ‘›n clients are dozens of organizations (Kairouz etÂ al. 2019) and kğ‘˜k is small), we can compute the largest and second largest label probabilities exactly via training (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models. However, it is challenging to compute them exactly when (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} is large. To address the computational challenge, we develop a Monte Carlo algorithm to estimate them with probabilistic guarantees via training Nğ‘N instead of (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models.

Evaluation:Â  We empirically evaluate our method on MNIST (LeCun, Cortes, and Burges 1998) and Human Activity Recognition datasets (Anguita etÂ al. 2013). We distribute the training examples in MNIST to clients to simulate federated learning scenarios, while the Human Activity Recognition dataset represents a real-world federated learning scenario, where each user is a client. We use the popular FedAvg developed by GoogleÂ (McMahan etÂ al. 2017) as the base federated learning algorithm. Moreover, we use certified accuracy as our evaluation metric, which is a lower bound of the testing accuracy that a method can provably achieve no matter how the malicious clients tamper their local training data and model updates. For instance, our ensemble FedAvg with N=500ğ‘500N=500 and k=10ğ‘˜10k=10 can achieve a certified accuracy of 88% on MNIST when evenly distributing the training examples among 1,000 clients and 20 of them are malicious.

In summary, our key contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    Theory: We propose ensemble federated learning, the first provably secure federated learning method against malicious clients. We derive a certified security level for our ensemble federated learning. Moreover, we prove that our derived certified security level is tight.

  • â€¢

    Algorithm: We propose a Monte Carlo algorithm to compute our certified security level in practice.

  • â€¢

    Evaluation: We evaluate our methods on MNIST and Human Activity Recognition datasets.

All our proofs are shown in Supplemental Material.

Background on Federated Learning

Assuming we have nğ‘›n clients ğ‚={1,2,â‹¯,n}ğ‚12â‹¯ğ‘›\mathbf{C}=\{1,2,\cdots,n\} and a cloud server in a federated learning setting. The iğ‘–ith client holds some local training dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}, where i=1,2,â‹¯,nğ‘–12â‹¯ğ‘›i=1,2,\cdots,n. Existing federated learning methods (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. 2016; McMahan etÂ al. 2017; Wang etÂ al. 2020; Li etÂ al. 2020b) mainly focus on learning a single global model for the nğ‘›n clients. Specifically, the server maintains a global model and each client maintains a local model. Then, federated learning iteratively performs the following three steps, which are shown in Algorithm 1. In Step I, the server sends the current global model to the clients.111The server may select a subset of clients, but we assume the server sends the global model to all clients for convenience. In Step II, each client trains a local model via fine-tuning the global model to its local training dataset. In particular, each client performs localIter iterations of stochastic gradient descent with a learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta to train its local model. Then, each client sends its model update (i.e., the difference between the local model and the global model) to the server. In Step III, the server aggregates the clientsâ€™ model updates according to some aggregation rule Agg and uses the aggregated model update to update the global model. The three steps are repeated for globalIter iterations. Existing federated learning algorithms essentially use different aggregation rules in Step III. For instance, Google developed FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al. 2017), which computes the average of the clientsâ€™ model updates weighted by the sizes of their local training datasets as the aggregated model update to update the global model.

We call such a federated learning algorithm that learns a single global model base federated learning algorithm and denote it as ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. Note that given any subset of the nğ‘›n clients ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C}, a base federated learning algorithm can learn a global model for them. Specifically, the server learns a global model via iteratively performing the three steps between the server and the given subset of clients.

Our Ensemble Federated Learning

Unlike single-global-model federated learning, our ensemble federated learning trains multiple global models, each of which is trained using the base algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} and a subsample with kğ‘˜k clients sampled from the nğ‘›n clients uniformly at random without replacement. Among the nğ‘›n clients ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C}, we have (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} subsamples with kğ‘˜k clients. Therefore, (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models can be trained in total if we train a global model using each subsample. For a given testing input ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, these global models may predict different labels for it. We define pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} as the fraction of the (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models that predict label iğ‘–i for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, where i=1,2,â‹¯,Lğ‘–12â‹¯ğ¿i=1,2,\cdots,L. We call pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} label probability. Note that pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} is an integer multiplication of 1(nk)1binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜\frac{1}{{n\choose k}}, which we will leverage to derive a tight security guarantee of ensemble federated learning. Moreover, pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} can also be viewed as the probability that a global model trained on a random subsample with kğ‘˜k clients predicts label iğ‘–i for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. Our ensemble global model predicts the label with the largest label probability for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}, i.e., we define:

Then, hâ„h provably predicts yğ‘¦y for ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} when at most mâˆ—superscriptğ‘šm^{*} clients in ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C} become malicious, i.e., we have:

hâ€‹(ğ‚â€²,ğ±)=hâ€‹(ğ‚,ğ±)=y,âˆ€ğ‚â€²,Mâ€‹(ğ‚â€²)â‰¤mâˆ—,formulae-sequenceâ„superscriptğ‚â€²ğ±â„ğ‚ğ±ğ‘¦for-allsuperscriptğ‚â€²ğ‘€superscriptğ‚â€²superscriptğ‘š\displaystyle\;h(\mathbf{C^{\prime}},\mathbf{x})=h(\mathbf{C},\mathbf{x})=y,\forall\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq m^{*}, (7)

where mâˆ—superscriptğ‘šm^{*} is the largest integer mğ‘šm (0â‰¤mâ‰¤nâˆ’k0ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘˜0\leq m\leq n-k) that satisfies inequality (5).

Our TheoremÂ 1 is applicable to any base federated learning algorithm, any lower bound pyÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦\underline{p_{y}} of pysubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦p_{y} and any upper bound pÂ¯zsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘§\overline{p}_{z} of pzsubscriptğ‘ğ‘§p_{z} that satisfy (6). When the lower bound pyÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦\underline{p_{y}} and upper bound pÂ¯zsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘§\overline{p}_{z} are estimated more accurately, i.e., pyÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦\underline{p_{y}} and pÂ¯zsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘§\overline{p}_{z} are respectively closer to pysubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦p_{y} and pzsubscriptğ‘ğ‘§p_{z}, our certified security level may be larger. The following theorem shows that our derived certified security level is tight, i.e., when no assumptions on the base federated learning algorithm are made, it is impossible to derive a certified security level that is larger than ours for the given probability bounds pyÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦\underline{p_{y}} and pÂ¯zsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘§\overline{p}_{z}.

Theorem 2.

Suppose pyÂ¯+pÂ¯zâ‰¤1Â¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘§1\underline{p_{y}}+\overline{p}_{z}\leq 1. For any ğ‚â€²superscriptğ‚â€²\mathbf{C^{\prime}} satisfying Mâ€‹(ğ‚â€²)>mâˆ—ğ‘€superscriptğ‚â€²superscriptğ‘šM(\mathbf{C^{\prime}})>m^{*}, i.e., at least mâˆ—+1superscriptğ‘š1m^{*}+1 clients are malicious, there exists a base federated learning algorithm ğ’œâˆ—superscriptğ’œ\mathcal{A}^{*} that satisfies (6) but hâ€‹(ğ‚â€²,ğ±)â‰ yâ„superscriptğ‚â€²ğ±ğ‘¦h(\mathbf{C^{\prime}},\mathbf{x})\neq y or there exist ties.

Computing the Certified Security Level

Suppose we are given nğ‘›n clients ğ‚ğ‚\mathbf{C}, a base federated learning algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, a subsample size kğ‘˜k, and a testing dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} with dğ‘‘d testing examples. For each testing example ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t} in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, we aim to compute its label y^tsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{y}_{t} predicted by our ensemble global model hâ„h and the corresponding certified security level m^tâˆ—superscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡\hat{m}_{t}^{*}. To compute the certified security level based on our TheoremÂ 1, we need a lower bound py^tÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} of the largest label probability py^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} and an upper bound pÂ¯z^tsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} of the second largest label probability pz^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}. When (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} is small, we can compute the exact label probabilities via training (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models. When (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} is large, we propose a Monte Carlo algorithm to estimate the predicted label and the two probability bounds for all testing examples in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} simultaneously with a confidence level 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha via training Nğ‘N of the (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models.

Computing predicted label and probability bounds for one testing example:Â  We first discuss how to compute the predicted label y^tsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{y}_{t} and probability bounds py^tÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} and pÂ¯z^tsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} for one testing example ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t}. We sample Nğ‘N subsamples with kğ‘˜k clients from the nğ‘›n clients uniformly at random without replacement and use them to train Nğ‘N global models g1,g2,â‹¯,gNsubscriptğ‘”1subscriptğ‘”2â‹¯subscriptğ‘”ğ‘g_{1},g_{2},\cdots,g_{N}. We use the Nğ‘N global models to predict labels for ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t} and count the frequency of each label. We treat the label with the largest frequency as the predicted label y^tsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{y}_{t}. Recall that, based on the definition of label probability, a global model trained on a random subsample with kğ‘˜k clients predicts label y^tsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{y}_{t} for ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t} with the label probability py^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡p_{\hat{y}_{t}}. Therefore, the frequency Ny^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡N_{\hat{y}_{t}} of the label y^tsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{y}_{t} among the Nğ‘N global models follows a binomial distribution Bâ€‹(N,py^t)ğµğ‘subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡B(N,p_{\hat{y}_{t}}) with parameters Nğ‘N and py^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡p_{\hat{y}_{t}}. Thus, given Ny^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡N_{\hat{y}_{t}} and Nğ‘N, we can use the standard one-sided Clopper-Pearson methodÂ (Clopper and Pearson 1934) to estimate a lower bound py^tÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} of py^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} with a confidence level 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha. Specifically, we have py^tÂ¯=â„¬â€‹(Î±;Ny^t,Nâˆ’Ny^t+1)Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡â„¬ğ›¼subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡1\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}=\mathcal{B}\left({\alpha};N_{\hat{y}_{t}},N-N_{\hat{y}_{t}}+1\right), where â„¬â€‹(q;v,w)â„¬ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘¤\mathcal{B}(q;v,w) is the qğ‘qth quantile from a beta distribution with shape parameters vğ‘£v and wğ‘¤w. Moreover, we can estimate pÂ¯z^t=1âˆ’py^tÂ¯â‰¥1âˆ’py^tâ‰¥pztsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡1Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}=1-\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}\geq 1-p_{\hat{y}_{t}}\geq{p}_{z_{t}} as an upper bound of pz^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}.

Computing predicted labels and probability bounds for dğ‘‘d testing examples:Â  One method to compute the predicted labels and probability bounds for the dğ‘‘d testing examples is to apply the above process to each testing example individually. However, such method is computationally intractable because it requires training Nğ‘N global models for every testing example. To address the computational challenge, we propose a method that only needs to train Nğ‘N global models in total. Our idea is to split Î±ğ›¼\alpha among the dğ‘‘d testing examples. Specifically, we follow the above process to train Nğ‘N global models and use them to predict labels for the dğ‘‘d testing examples. For each testing example ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t}, we estimate the lower bound py^tÂ¯=â„¬â€‹(Î±d;Ny^t,Nâˆ’Ny^t+1)Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡â„¬ğ›¼ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡1\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}=\mathcal{B}\left(\frac{\alpha}{d};N_{\hat{y}_{t}},N-N_{\hat{y}_{t}}+1\right) with confidence level 1âˆ’Î±/d1ğ›¼ğ‘‘1-\alpha/d instead of 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha. According to the Bonferroni correction, the simultaneous confidence level of estimating the lower bounds for the dğ‘‘d testing examples is 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha. Following the above process, we still estimate pÂ¯z^t=1âˆ’py^tÂ¯subscriptÂ¯ğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡1Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}}=1-\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} as an upper bound of pz^tsubscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} for each testing example.

Complete algorithm: AlgorithmÂ 2 shows our algorithm to compute the predicted labels and certified security levels for the dğ‘‘d testing examples in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}. The function Sample&Train randomly samples Nğ‘N subsamples with kğ‘˜k clients and trains Nğ‘N global models using the base federated learning algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. Given the probability bounds py^tÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} and pÂ¯z^tsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘subscript^ğ‘§ğ‘¡\overline{p}_{\hat{z}_{t}} for a testing example ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t}, the function SearchLevel finds the certified security level m^tâˆ—superscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡\hat{m}_{t}^{*} via finding the largest integer mğ‘šm that satisfies (5). For example, SearchLevel can simply start mğ‘šm from 0 and iteratively increase it by one until finding m^tâˆ—superscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡\hat{m}_{t}^{*}.

Probabilistic guarantees: In AlgorithmÂ 2, since we estimate the lower bound py^tÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}} using the Clopper-Pearson method, there is a probability that the estimated lower bound is incorrect, i.e., py^tÂ¯>py^tÂ¯subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\underline{p_{\hat{y}_{t}}}>p_{\hat{y}_{t}}. When the lower bound is estimated incorrectly for a testing example ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t}, the certified security level m^tâˆ—superscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡\hat{m}_{t}^{*} outputted by AlgorithmÂ 2 for ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t} may also be incorrect, i.e., there may exist an ğ‚â€²superscriptğ‚â€²\mathbf{C}^{\prime} such that Mâ€‹(ğ‚â€²)â‰¤m^tâˆ—ğ‘€superscriptğ‚â€²superscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*} but hâ€‹(ğ‚â€²,ğ±t)â‰ y^tâ„superscriptğ‚â€²subscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})\neq\hat{y}_{t}. In other words, our AlgorithmÂ 2 has probabilistic guarantees for its outputted certified security levels. However, in the following theorem, we prove the probability that AlgorithmÂ 2 returns an incorrect certified security level for at least one testing example is at most Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

Theorem 3.

The probability that AlgorithmÂ 2 returns an incorrect certified security level for at least one testing example in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is bounded by Î±ğ›¼\alpha, which is equivalent to:

Pr (âˆ©ğ±tâˆˆğ’Ÿ(hâ€‹(ğ‚â€²,ğ±t)=y^t,âˆ€ğ‚â€²,Mâ€‹(ğ‚â€²)â‰¤m^tâˆ—|y^tâ‰ ABSTAIN))subscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ’Ÿformulae-sequenceâ„superscriptğ‚â€²subscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡for-allsuperscriptğ‚â€²ğ‘€superscriptğ‚â€²conditionalsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ABSTAIN\displaystyle(\cap_{\mathbf{x}_{t}\in\mathcal{D}}(h(\mathbf{C}^{\prime},\mathbf{x}_{t})=\hat{y}_{t},\forall\mathbf{C}^{\prime},M(\mathbf{C}^{\prime})\leq\hat{m}_{t}^{*}|\hat{y}_{t}\neq\text{ABSTAIN}))
â‰¥1âˆ’Î±.absent1ğ›¼\displaystyle\geq 1-\alpha. (8)

Note that when the probability bounds are estimated deterministically, e.g., when (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} is small and the exact label probabilities can be computed via training (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models, the certified security level obtained from our TheoremÂ 1 is also deterministic.

Experiments

Experimental Setup

Datasets, model architectures, and base algorithm: We use MNIST (LeCun, Cortes, and Burges 1998) and Human Activity Recognition (HAR) datasets (Anguita etÂ al. 2013). MNIST is used to simulate federated learning scenarios, while HAR represents a real-world federated learning scenario. Specifically, MNIST has 60,000 training examples and 10,000 testing examples. We consider n=1,000ğ‘›1000n=1,000 clients and we split them into 101010 groups. We assign a training example with label lğ‘™l to the lğ‘™lth group of clients with probability qğ‘q and assign it to each remaining group with a probability 1âˆ’q91ğ‘9\frac{1-q}{9}. After assigning a training example to a group, we distribute it to a client in the group uniformly at random. The parameter qğ‘q controls local training data distribution on clients and we call qğ‘q degree of non-IID. q=0.1ğ‘0.1q=0.1 means that clientsâ€™ local training data are IID, while a larger qğ‘q indicates a larger degree of non-IID. By default, we set q=0.5ğ‘0.5q=0.5. However, we will study the impact of qğ‘q (degree of non-IID) on our method. HAR includes human activity data from 30 users, each of which is a client. The task is to predict a userâ€™s activity based on the sensor signals (e.g., acceleration) collected from the userâ€™s smartphone. There are 6 possible activities (e.g., walking, sitting, and standing), indicating a 6-class classification problem. There are 10,299 examples in total and each example has 561 features. We use 75% of each userâ€™s examples as training examples and the rest as testing examples.

We consider a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture (shown in Supplemental Material) for MNIST. For HAR, we consider a deep neural network (DNN) with two fully-connected hidden layers, each of which contains 256 neurons and uses ReLU as the activation function. We use the popular FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al. 2017) as the base federated learning algorithm. Recall that a base federated learning algorithm has hyperparameters (shown in AlgorithmÂ 1): gâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Iâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹rğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ¼ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ŸglobalIter, lâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Iâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹rğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ¼ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ŸlocalIter, learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta, and batch size. Table 1 summarizes these hyperparameters for FedAvg in our experiments. In particular, we set the gâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Iâ€‹tâ€‹eâ€‹rğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ¼ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ŸglobalIter in Table 1 because FedAvg converges with such settings.

Evaluation metric: We use certified accuracy as our evaluation metric. Specifically, we define the certified accuracy at mğ‘šm malicious clients (denoted as CA@â€‹m@ğ‘š@m) for a federated learning method as the fraction of testing examples in the testing dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} whose labels are correctly predicted by the method and whose certified security levels are at least mğ‘šm. Formally, we define CA@â€‹m@ğ‘š@m as follows:

CAâ€‹@â€‹m=âˆ‘ğ±tâˆˆğ’Ÿğ•€â€‹(y^t=yt)â‹…ğ•€â€‹(m^tâˆ—â‰¥m)|ğ’Ÿ|,CA@ğ‘šsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ’Ÿâ‹…ğ•€subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ•€superscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘šğ’Ÿ\displaystyle\text{CA}@m=\frac{\sum_{\mathbf{x}_{t}\in\mathcal{D}}\mathbb{I}(\hat{y}_{t}=y_{t})\cdot\mathbb{I}(\hat{m}_{t}^{*}\geq m)}{|\mathcal{D}|}, (9)

where ğ•€ğ•€\mathbb{I} is the indicator function, ytsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡y_{t} is the true label for ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t}, and y^tsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{y}_{t} and m^tâˆ—superscriptsubscript^ğ‘šğ‘¡\hat{m}_{t}^{*} are respectively the predicted label and certified security level for ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t}. Intuitively, CA@â€‹m@ğ‘š@m means that when at most mğ‘šm clients are malicious, the accuracy of the federated learning method for ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is at least CA@â€‹m@ğ‘š@m no matter what attacks the malicious clients use (i.e., no matter how the malicious clients tamper their local training data and model updates). Note that CA@â€‹0@0@0 reduces to the standard accuracy when there are no malicious clients.

When we can compute the exact label probabilities via training (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} global models, the CA@â€‹m@ğ‘š@m of our ensemble global model hâ„h computed using the certified security levels derived from TheoremÂ 1 is deterministic. When (nk)binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜{n\choose k} is large, we estimate predicted labels and certified security levels using AlgorithmÂ 2, and thus our CA@â€‹m@ğ‘š@m has a confidence level 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha according to TheoremÂ 3.

Parameter settings: Our method has three parameters: Nğ‘N, kğ‘˜k, and Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Unless otherwise mentioned, we adopt the following default settings for them: N=500ğ‘500N=500, Î±=0.001ğ›¼0.001\alpha=0.001, k=10ğ‘˜10k=10 for MNIST, and k=2ğ‘˜2k=2 for HAR. Under such default setting for HAR, we have (nk)=(302)=435<N=500binomialğ‘›ğ‘˜binomial302435ğ‘500{n\choose k}={30\choose 2}=435<N=500 and we can compute the exact label probabilities via training 435 global models. Therefore, we have deterministic certified accuracy for HAR under the default setting. We will explore the impact of each parameter while using the default settings for the other two parameters. For HAR, we set k=4ğ‘˜4k=4 when exploring the impact of Nğ‘N (i.e., FigureÂ 4(b)) and Î±ğ›¼\alpha (i.e., FigureÂ 5(b)) since the default setting k=2ğ‘˜2k=2 gives deterministic certified accuracy, making Nğ‘N and Î±ğ›¼\alpha not relevant.

Experimental Results

Single-global-model FedAvg vs. ensemble FedAvg: FigureÂ 2 compares single-global-model FedAvg and ensemble FedAvg with respect to certified accuracy on the two datasets. When there are no malicious clients (i.e., m=0ğ‘š0m=0), single-global-model FedAvg is more accurate than ensemble FedAvg. This is because ensemble FedAvg uses a subsample of clients to train each global model. However, single-global-model FedAvg has 0 certified accuracy when just one client is malicious. This is because a single malicious client can arbitrarily manipulate the global model learnt by FedAvgÂ (Blanchard etÂ al. 2017). However, the certified accuracy of ensemble FedAvg reduces to 0 when up to 61 and 9 clients (6.1% and 30%) are malicious on MNIST and HAR, respectively. Note that it is unknown whether existing Byzantine-robust federated learning methods have non-zero certified accuracy when m>0ğ‘š0m>0, and thus we cannot compare ensemble FedAvg with them.

Impact of kğ‘˜k, Nğ‘N, and Î±ğ›¼\alpha:Â  Figure 3, 4, and 5 show the impact of kğ‘˜k, Nğ‘N, and Î±ğ›¼\alpha, respectively. kğ‘˜k achieves a trade-off between accuracy under no malicious clients and security under malicious clients. Specifically, when kğ‘˜k is larger, the ensemble global model is more accurate at m=0ğ‘š0m=0, but the certified accuracy drops more quickly to 0 as mğ‘šm increases. This is because when kğ‘˜k is larger, it is more likely for the sampled kğ‘˜k clients to include malicious ones. The certified accuracy increases as Nğ‘N or Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases. This is because training more global models or a larger Î±ğ›¼\alpha allows AlgorithmÂ 2 to estimate tighter probability bounds and larger certified security levels. When Nğ‘N increases from 100 to 500, the certified accuracy increases significantly. However, when Nğ‘N further grows to 1,000, the increase of certified accuracy is marginal. Our results show that we donâ€™t need to train too many global models in practice, as the certified accuracy saturates when Nğ‘N is larger than some threshold.

Impact of degree of non-IID qğ‘q:Â  FigureÂ 6 shows the certified accuracy of our ensemble FedAvg on MNIST when the clientsâ€™ local training data have different degrees of non-IID. We observe that the certified accuracy drops when qğ‘q increases from 0.5 to 0.9, which represents a high degree of non-IID. However, the certified accuracy is still high when mğ‘šm is small for q=0.9ğ‘0.9q=0.9, e.g., the certified accuracy is still 83% when m=10ğ‘š10m=10. This is because although each global model trained using a subsample of clients is less accurate when the local training data are highly non-IID, the ensemble of multiple global models is still accurate.

Related Work

In federated learning, the first category of studiesÂ (Smith etÂ al. 2017; Li etÂ al. 2020b; Wang etÂ al. 2020; Liu etÂ al. 2020; Peng etÂ al. 2020) aim to design federated learning methods that can learn more accurate global models and/or analyze their convergence properties. For instance, FedMA (Wang etÂ al. 2020) constructs the global model via matching and averaging the hidden elements in a neural network with similar feature extraction signatures. The second category of studiesÂ (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. 2016; McMahan etÂ al. 2017; Wen etÂ al. 2017; Alistarh etÂ al. 2017; Lee etÂ al. 2017; Sahu etÂ al. 2018; Bernstein etÂ al. 2018; Vogels, Karimireddy, and Jaggi 2019; Yurochkin etÂ al. 2019; Mohri, Sivek, and Suresh 2019; Wang etÂ al. 2020; Li, Wen, and He 2020; Li etÂ al. 2020c; Hamer, Mohri, and Suresh 2020; Rothchild etÂ al. 2020; Malinovsky etÂ al. 2020) aim to improve the communication efficiency between the clients and server via sparsification, quantization, and/or encoding of the model updates sent from the clients to the server. The third category of studiesÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al. 2017; Geyer, Klein, and Nabi 2017; Hitaj, Ateniese, and Perez-Cruz 2017; Melis etÂ al. 2019; Zhu, Liu, and Han 2019; Mohri, Sivek, and Suresh 2019; Wang, Tong, and Shi 2020; Li etÂ al. 2020a) aim to explore the privacy/fairness issues of federated learning and their defenses.These studies often assume a single global model is shared among the clients. Smith et al. (Smith etÂ al. 2017) proposed to learn a customized model for each client via multi-task learning.

Our work is on security of federated learning, which is orthogonal to the studies above. Multiple studiesÂ (Fang etÂ al. 2020; Bagdasaryan etÂ al. 2020; Xie, Koyejo, and Gupta 2019; Bhagoji etÂ al. 2019) showed that the global modelâ€™s accuracy can be significantly downgraded by malicious clients. Existing defenses against malicious clients leverage Byzantine-robust aggregation rules such as KrumÂ (Blanchard etÂ al. 2017), trimmed mean (Yin etÂ al. 2018), coordinate-wise median (Yin etÂ al. 2018), and BulyanÂ (Mhamdi, Guerraoui, and Rouault 2018). However, they cannot provably guarantee that the global modelâ€™s predicted label for a testing example is not affected by malicious clients. As a result, they may be broken by strong attacks that carefully craft the model updates sent from the malicious clients to the server, e.g., (Fang etÂ al. 2020). We propose ensemble federated learning whose predicted label for a testing example is provably not affected by a bounded number of malicious clients.

We note that ensemble methods were also proposed as provably secure defenses (e.g.,Â (Jia, Cao, and Gong 2020)) against data poisoning attacks. However, they are insufficient to defend against malicious clients that can manipulate both the local training data and the model updates. In particular, a provably secure defense against data poisoning attacks guarantees that the label predicted for a testing example is unaffected by a bounded number of poisoned training examples. However, a single malicious client can poison an arbitrary number of its local training examples, breaking the assumption of provably secure defenses against data poisoning attacks.

Conclusion

In this work, we propose ensemble federated learning and derive its tight provable security guarantee against malicious clients. Moreover, we propose an algorithm to compute the certified security levels. Our empirical results on two datasets show that our ensemble federated learning can effectively defend against malicious clients with provable security guarantees. Interesting future work includes estimating the probability bounds deterministically and considering the internal structure of a base federated learning algorithm to further improve our provable security guarantees.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 3

Based on the Clopper-Pearson method, for each testing example ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}_{t}, we have:
